title: 107_s1196
content: The "Small Business Investment Company Amendments Act of 2001" amends subsidy fees and conflicts of interest regulations in the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. Subsidy fees are adjusted to not exceed 1.38 percent per year, effective October 1, 2001. Conflicts of interest disclosure requirements are modified. Section 312 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended by removing a specific disclosure requirement. Penalties for false statements are also addressed. Penalties for false statements under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 and the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 are amended to include criminal and civil penalties. SEC. 5. REMOVAL OR SUSPENSION OF MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS. The term 'management official' includes various roles in the management of a licensee. The Administrator can remove a management official if they have willfully violated the Act, regulations, or final cease-and-desist orders. A management official can be removed if they have willfully breached a fiduciary duty involving personal dishonesty. The notice of intention to remove must state the grounds and schedule a hearing within 30 to 60 days. The Administrator can set an earlier or later date upon request with valid reasons. The Administrator may issue orders of removal from office if a management official consents or if grounds for removal are established after a hearing. Orders become effective after 30 days unless issued upon consent. The Administrator has the authority to suspend or prohibit a management official from participating in the affairs of the licensee if deemed necessary for protection. The suspension or prohibition becomes effective upon serving notice to the official. The Administrator can suspend or prohibit a management official from participating in a licensee's affairs for protection. The suspension or prohibition takes effect upon notice and remains in place until administrative proceedings are completed or charges are dismissed. Judicial review can be sought within 10 days of the suspension or prohibition. The Administrator can suspend or prohibit a management official from participating in a licensee's affairs if charged with a felony involving dishonesty or breach of trust. The suspension remains in place until administrative proceedings are completed or charges are dismissed. Judicial review can be sought within 10 days of the suspension. The Administrator has the authority to suspend or prohibit a management official from involvement in a licensee's affairs if charged with a felony related to dishonesty or breach of trust. The suspension remains in effect until the case is resolved, and if convicted, the Administrator can issue an order for the official's removal. A not guilty verdict does not prevent the Administrator from taking action to suspend or remove the official. The Administrator can suspend or remove a management official from a licensee's affairs if charged with a felony related to dishonesty or breach of trust. The official must be notified, and a hearing will be held in the relevant jurisdiction. After the hearing, a decision will be made within 90 days. The Administrator can modify, terminate, or set aside any order issued under this section at any time, with proper notice and in the manner deemed appropriate. Judicial review of an order issued under this section shall be exclusively as provided in this subsection. Any party to a hearing under this section may seek review of an order by filing a petition in the court of appeals within 30 days. The Administrator must be notified, and the record in the proceeding will be filed with the court. Upon filing a petition, the court has exclusive jurisdiction to affirm, modify, terminate, or set aside the Administrator's order. The court's judgment is final but can be reviewed by the Supreme Court. Judicial review does not act as a stay of proceedings. The commencement of judicial review proceedings does not stay any order issued by the Administrator under this section. SEC. 6. REDUCTION OF FEES. Two-Year Reduction of Section 7(a) Fees: Guarantee fees for loans approved during a 2-year period starting October 1, 2002, will have reduced rates based on the total loan amount. Annual fees for loans approved during the same period will also be adjusted. The annual fee for loans approved during a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, will be 0.25 percent of the outstanding balance of the deferred participation share of the loan. Additionally, guarantee fees for loans approved during this period will have reduced rates based on the total loan amount. During a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, the Small Business Administration will waive upfront guarantee fees for loans made under certain titles. Loans and financings during this period will be treated as separate programs for budgetary purposes. The amendments made to the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 will only be effective if funds are made available through appropriations Acts. The amendments made by this section, defined in the Federal Credit Reform Act of 1990, will be effective on October 1, 2002.
